III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Initial documentation
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4152
Section (1) At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
Description resident’s case record:
(g) Authorization to provide medical, dental, and surgical care
and treatment as provided in section 14 a (1), (2), and (3) of 1973
PA 116, MCL 722.124a.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 6/14/24 facility staff brought Youth K to the hospital without the
required documents.
Investigation Interviews:
I notified Chief Administrator of the allegation.
On 6/18/24 I notified Complainant of the investigation assignment
by email and attempted to reach her by phone to no avail.
I interviewed Hospital Social Worker on 6/20/24. She indicated an
unidentified staff from Christ Child House brought Youth K to the
hospital for a psychiatric evaluation on 6/14/24 without his medical
authorization card and a court order. The unidentified staff texted
the facility and was able to produce the medical authorization card
in a timely manner. However, Hospital Social Worker said the
third-party evaluator also requires a court order which was not
provided and delayed the referral process. While waiting for the
court order, Hospital Social Worker ended up obtaining permission
directly from Youth K’s father. Youth K was evaluated and
released back to Christ Child House the next morning.
I notified Youth K’s Foster Care Worker of the investigation
assignment. She had no information to provide relative to the
allegation.
I interviewed Staff 1 onsite on 6/20/24. She has worked at the
facility for one year. Staff 1 said on 6/14/24 at 2pm Residential
Director asked her to pick Youth K up from school and transport
him to Children’s Hospital because the school told her he had
thoughts of suicide.
2

Staff 1 said she was aware of the hospital admission process
because had taken several other youths there for psychiatric
evaluations. Staff 1 said she provided a copy of the medical
authorization card within ten minutes after Complainant requested
it. She said Complainant acknowledged receipt of the card and
requested no additional documents. Staff 1 remained at the
hospital with Youth K until 6/15/24 at 7am when she was relieved
by another staff.
I interviewed Clinical Director at the facility on 6/20/24. She said
Youth K has been to the hospital four times recently for psychiatric
evaluations (4/7/24, 4/12/23, 6/9/24 and 6/14/24). Clinical Director
indicated that medical authorization cards are kept in the
children’s medical files and are available to staff afterhours for
emergencies. However, she said Christ Child House does not
always receive copies of the court orders from the referral source
and hospitals have never asked for them before this complaint
was filed.
At my request, Clinical Director contacted Children’s Hospital
Social Work Department Supervisor on 6/21/24. She said the
Hospital Social Work Supervisor told her Children’s Hospital
needs a court order identifying the child’s guardian and legal
status. They can no longer accept the word of CCI staff as to who
is legally responsible to sign consents – either parent/guardian or
MDHHS. Children’s Hospital now needs the court order at check-
in to minimize delays in any processes for mental health
screenings or otherwise. Previously the third-party assessor
completed the mental health screenings without consent from
legal guardian/MDHHS and consent was only required if in-patient
treatment was recommended.
Given the apparent new change in documents required by
Children’s Hospital and the third-party contractor, moving forward
the Chief Administrator and Clinical Director committed to
diligently attempting to obtain all court orders from MDHHS foster
care workers identifying guardianship of current children placed at
the facility. They also plan to assure they have said court order
prior to the placement of children to their facility.
The facility does not have a written procedure listing the specific
documents staff must present when checking a youth in for
treatment at a hospital.
Documents reviewed:
3

Medical authorization card dated 6/1/24, which provides consent
to the routine, non-surgical medical care and emergency
medical/surgical treatment of Youth K.
Analysis There is no licensing rule requiring CCI’s to maintain court orders
identifying guardianship in the child’s records.
Staff 1 provided Complainant with a copy of Youth K’s medical
authorization card in a timely manner, but neither Staff 1 nor the
facility had Youth K’s court order so it could not be provided to the
hospital at the time of check-in.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
